Although the study uses task-evoked fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=36, ages 20–35) and addresses vocal emotional processing (a form of social communication), it does not report any group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or coordinate tables/generalizable voxelwise contrasts for the healthy group. The paper presents ROI-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical/network analyses (Power-264 atlas, OMST filtering, FC metrics) rather than whole-brain voxelwise activation results. This fails the explicit inclusion requirement for at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map, so the study must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task involved social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; implicit bias and responses to facial disfigurement). Sample includes a healthy adult group (N=31, ages 18–35) reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (pre- vs post-treatment faces) with familywise-error correction and cluster thresholds; results are described in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not restricted-age subgroup only). Therefore eligible for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35) investigating social interaction perception using task paradigms (viewing dyadic and alone interaction videos) during fMRI. The study reports whole-brain GLM estimation and group-level whole-brain analyses for functional localizers (interaction > scrambled, bodies > objects, faces > objects, mentalizing > pain) used to define ROIs and provides whole-brain searchlight results; these constitute group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain analyses in a healthy sample. The task is clearly social (perception/understanding of others, social interaction). No exclusion criteria apply (not an ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only paper, healthy adults included and reported). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (cyberball social exclusion) in healthy adult participants (N=71 females, age 21.7 ± 2.3), meeting the sample criterion (healthy adults 17–65). The study reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate analyses (initial whole-brain threshold p<0.001 uncorrected with clusters surviving FWE correction via small-volume correction) and provides peak coordinates and statistical maps for group-level contrasts. The task probes social-affiliation/ostracism and results are reported at the group level for healthy participants (within- and between-group contrasts across healthy subgroups). Although the sample is female-only (limits generalizability), the paper reports whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and thus satisfies the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a socioemotional Face Processing Task (fearful vs. neutral faces) targeting social cognition/empathy. Sample: 49 healthy adults (ages 18–33), meeting the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (F > N and N > F contrasts) with TFCE/FWE correction, coordinates, figures and exploratory whole-brain analyses clearly attributed to the healthy group. It also includes ROI and connectivity analyses, but not exclusively; whole-brain activation maps are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and examines face perception (a social-related process), the full text presents analyses focused on ROI-based multivariate pattern analyses (MVPA) and regression of behavioral models onto ROI/probabilistic visual-field masks. The paper does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., a whole-brain GLM contrast) for the healthy/control group in the main text or figures/tables described; instead results are reported for predefined ROIs and probabilistic visual field regions. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement for at least one clearly reported whole-brain univariate task activation map and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact), using a task probing social communication/attention. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (initial N=34; fMRI analyses reported on 30 participants; mean age ~21.7, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY; LIVE and REPLAY > REST) analyzed with random-effects GLM, cluster-level FWE correction, and tables/figures of significant clusters. Although connectivity and interbrain synchronization analyses are also reported, the study clearly includes whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study in 44 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4) using a social interactive task (pattern game) manipulating cooperation/competition and turn-based vs concurrent interaction. The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction and present cluster-level results and t-maps/coordinates for contrasts among conditions, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Sample falls within 17–65 and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (trustworthiness/fear appraisal of faces). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=17; ages 18–45) with results reported separately alongside a BPD group. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (group-level mixed-effects analyses, task contrasts such as trustworthiness>fearfulness and fearfulness>trustworthiness) and provides peak coordinates and cluster results (e.g., MNI peaks, Supplementary Tables), not only ROI findings. Whole-brain contrasts and group comparisons are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. It does not violate exclusion criteria (not limited to ROI-only, not only connectivity, includes healthy adult whole-brain maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 18–22). The task is social (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma; assesses responses to cooperation/defection—perception/understanding of others, social interaction). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM; cluster-based thresholding, Z-statistics, reported clusters/tables and figures) for healthy participants and also reports ROI analyses. Results for healthy/control groups are clearly described and generalizable within the adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task-evoked maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma probing cooperation/trust), enrolled healthy adult participants (N=20 males, age range 21–37), and reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked group-level results (one-sample t-tests, flexible factorial analyses; FWE cluster-corrected maps and tables of activations). Healthy-group effects are reported and generalized to the healthy sample (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated (not an ROI-only, resting-state, or non-empirical paper; ages within 17–65). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study uses fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing (Toy Story), a stimulus with clear social-cognitive demands (theory of mind, social interactions). The sample includes a healthy adult group (final N=21 adults) within the target age range and reported adult-group results separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level statistical maps of inter-subject correlation (within-group inter-SC maps and Adult vs. Child contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction and peak coordinates, which are whole-brain task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. Although the analysis uses inter-subject correlation rather than a traditional GLM, the reported group-level voxel/nodewise statistical maps satisfy the criterion of whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social feedback task (social inclusion/exclusion) in a healthy sample (N=56 analyzed; ages 17–20), which falls within the review’s adult range (17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunctions) with voxelwise familywise-error correction and provides peak coordinates and conjunction maps. Analyses are reported for the healthy cohort (results not limited to a narrow subgroup), and are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Participants are adolescents (N=34; ages 14–18, mean 16.3). Inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65 or a separately reported adult subgroup. This study does not report a separate adult (≥17) healthy group or analyses restricted to adults, and the sample is predominantly under 17. Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social reward and reports whole-brain group-level results (cluster coordinates in social-processing regions), the participant age range violates the sample inclusion criterion. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful, social-irrelevant, non-social conditions). It reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables/figures of peak coordinates for the healthy participant groups. A healthy younger adult group (age 20–29) is analyzed and reported separately, meeting the 17–65 age requirement. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and presents whole-brain task activation maps/generalizable effects for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria appear violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of others varying by race and socioeconomic status), conducted in healthy adult participants (60 adult males, mean age 23.8). The task is a task-evoked, event-related impression-formation paradigm using faces (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain second-level GLMs and exploratory whole-brain regression results (clusters for the main effect of status and a VMPFC cluster), in addition to ROI analyses. Whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates are described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (only ROIs, only connectivity, non-healthy sample, or no whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (intelligence/friendliness judgments), the authors explicitly restricted statistical searches to a set of a priori ROIs (amygdala, insula, IFG, ACC, thalamus, caudate, mOFC) and report ROI-constrained voxelwise results. The paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map generalizable to the healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for reporting whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked results and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study (Study 1) of emotion perception/social communication in healthy adult participants (N=25, ages 19–24). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (3×3 repeated-measures ANOVA, PFWE-corrected maps, tables of activations and contrasts) and ROI analyses. Results are reported for the healthy sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The task probes social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others’ emotions). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social role judgment task probing self- and other-referential processing (Perception and Understanding of Self and Others). Participants were healthy adult males (N=37, mean age 22.9) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Self vs. Celebrity; Friend vs. Celebrity) with voxelwise results and coordinates (FDR-corrected threshold reported) and tables/figures of activations. Analyses include whole-brain regression and gPPI but also report univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task-based fMRI including an explicit social cognition contrast (TOM vs Random) in a large sample of healthy adults (n=787, ages 22–35+). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps (Cohen's d and level 3 z maps) and provides cluster tables and figures; results for healthy participants are clearly presented. The analysis is not ROI-only, not limited to connectivity, and includes whole-brain task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (observation of cooperative vs affective social interactions) in healthy adults (N=36; ages ~24–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (parametric and categorical analyses) with thresholding and cluster/FDR-corrected maps, and provides tables of coordinates and figures of activations. Although the paper also includes DCM effective-connectivity analyses, it additionally reports whole-brain activation maps for the healthy control sample, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it should be included.

This is a task-based fMRI study of collaborative vs. individual label learning and retrieval (social communication/mentalizing), with healthy adult participants (N=70; ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Collaborative > Individual, Collaborative > Arbitrary) with cluster-level correction and a full Table 1 of peak coordinates and figures showing whole-brain maps. It is not ROI-only, nor connectivity- or resting-state-only, and results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for task-evoked whole-brain fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 23–38) performing a social decision-making task (iterated prisoner's dilemma) probing theory-of-mind/social cognition. The paper presents whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (conjunction vs control; contrasts COMP>COOP and COOP>COMP) with cluster-corrected results and tables of MNI coordinates, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical, not ROI-only (also includes PPI but primary whole-brain task activations are reported). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Although the study investigates social/attachment processing in healthy adults using fMRI, the reported neuroimaging results are resting-state, seed-based functional connectivity analyses (left/right caudate nucleus) measured after listening to narratives. The paper does not present any group-level, whole‑brain, univariate task-evoked activation maps (GLM task contrasts) from the healthy group; analyses focus on seed-based FC and behavioral ratings. Per the meta-analysis criteria, studies that report only seed-based or resting-state connectivity without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: The study uses task-based fMRI to investigate perception/understanding of others (social interactions). Participants are healthy adults (N=14, ages 20–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate analyses (interaction > independent; animate > physical) with peak MNI coordinates, figures, and supplementary whole-brain maps described in the text. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-adult samples. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore this study should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=27, right-handed males, ages 20–32) that examines social/affiliation-related processing (monogamy/adultery, attachment). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses: a whole-brain subtraction for the IAT (incongruent vs congruent) with reported clusters (left DLPFC/VLPFC, lingual gyrus, putamen) using cluster-level FWE correction, satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain activation map. Although the go/no-go contrast was additionally examined with an ROI constraint, the presence of whole-brain IAT results meets the inclusion criteria. The sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only) are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (romantic/affiliation stimuli) in healthy adult participants (n=20 heterosexual men, ages 22–50). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., sexual>neutral combined activation for all participants; romantic>neutral and romantic>sexual within-group contrasts; between-group contrasts), analyzed with random-effects FLAME and cluster-wise thresholding. Whole-brain results are presented in figures and tables of coordinates and described in the text. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or lack of healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social cognition (implicit/explicit theory-of-mind) in healthy adults (final N=22, mean age 24.4). The paper reports a group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM contrast (false-belief vs false-photograph) from an explicit general-belief localizer, thresholded at q(FDR)<0.05, with peak coordinates and whole-brain activation figure (Fig.2A). Thus it provides a univariate, group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for healthy adults, satisfying the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion. Although some analyses used ROIs for the implicit task, the presence and reporting of the whole-brain localizer contrast meet the meta-analysis requirements.

This is an fMRI study of social-emotional processing (schadenfreude and fremdscham) in healthy adults (N=34 males, ages 19–31), addressing perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SIT vs NEUT) with voxelwise FWE-corrected results and tables of coordinates (reported in text and Table 1), as well as conjunctions and parametric modulations—satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROIs/connectivity analyses are included, whole-brain activation maps for the healthy/control group are clearly presented and generalizable to adult healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=23, ages 18–27) and addresses social cognition (simulation of personally familiar others), it does NOT report a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map (e.g., a main effect or standard within-group contrast). The imaging results are based on multivariate analyses (searchlight MVPA/RSA and feature-selected RSA) and group-level voxelwise maps of multivariate pattern effects, rather than traditional univariate task activation contrasts. The inclusion criteria explicitly require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Because the paper’s primary maps are multivariate pattern maps rather than univariate activation maps, it fails the required whole-brain univariate evidence criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (Trust Game assessing reciprocity/altruism) conducted in healthy adults (imaging analyses on n=19, ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked GLM contrasts with coordinates and cluster results (see Table 3 and figures) clearly identified for the healthy sample. Whole-brain results are presented (not ROI-only), and although ICA is also reported, univariate whole-brain activation maps/contrasts are provided for healthy participants. No exclusion criteria are violated. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adults: neuroimaging cohort includes N=62 healthy participants aged 18–53 (within 17–65). Task: social decision-making with manipulated social information during simultaneous fMRI (‘hyperscanning’); univariate task-evoked GLM analyses performed at the group level (random-effects). The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise results (parametric regressors, contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction via nonparametric permutation (SnPM) and thresholding (p<.001, extent threshold), and provides statistical maps (NeuroVault). Results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=41, ages 18–24) that uses task-evoked social-related paradigms (decisions to select/share news, involving self- and other-relevant processing and mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (select > content, share > content, share > select) with whole-brain results and peak coordinates (Table 2) corrected for family-wise error (p < .05), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are presented and generalizable to healthy adults; analyses are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social action–outcome contingency; humor/laughter as social feedback) in healthy adults. Sample: 38 healthy adults aged 19–29 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., SELF vs OTHER; Group vs No laughter; interaction [(SELF_Group - SELF_No) - (OTHER_Group - OTHER_No)]) with voxelwise statistics and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides tables of coordinates and figures derived from the healthy participant group. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the paper also presents univariate whole-brain activation maps clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social/person knowledge retrieval in healthy adult participants (study 1: n=24, Mage=23.2; study 2: n=26, Mage=20.4), ages within 17–65. Tasks are explicitly social (person memory; retrieval of biographical, status, and personality-trait information). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., all memory > baseline; status memory > baseline; trait memory > baseline), with voxelwise FWE-corrected maps and coordinates provided (see Table S6 and Figures S3). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI in healthy adults, and whole-brain univariate results reported) and violates no exclusion criteria. Therefore include.

Study meets all inclusion criteria: healthy adult sample (final N=38, ages 18–30) performing a social-related task during fMRI (Social Detection Task assessing valence of naturalistic social interactions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (random-effects, full-factorial ANOVA) with whole-brain results and cluster-level FWE-corrected activations presented in Table 1 and figures (e.g., Social > Non-social contrast). Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes task-evoked whole-brain maps). Therefore the study should be included.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30–32 females; mean age 22.7) using social cognition tasks (mentalizing, empathy for pain, prosocial decisions). Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Mentalizing > baseline; Dissimilar > Similar; Painful > Non-Painful) with cluster-level corrected inference and tables/coordinates. Analyses and results are clearly presented for the healthy sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. Does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

The study is an fMRI task-based investigation of social competition (social comparison/mentalizing) in healthy adult participants (n=20 right-handed females, ages 18–35). It reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (random-effects GLM) with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Competition > No Competition at feedback) and an activation table with Talairach coordinates and cluster-corrected thresholds. The task explicitly probes social-related processing (competition, social referencing, mentalizing). Results for the healthy adult sample are reported directly and are generalizable to healthy adults within the review age range. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical task fMRI study in healthy adults (25 right-handed female participants, mean age 23.2). The task is social cognition/mentalizing about friends vs kin (affiliation/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (friend > kin, parametric analyses across network layers) with cluster-corrected results and MNI coordinates presented in tables and figures. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of prosocial learning in healthy adults (n=31 males, age 19–32) using a social task (choices for self, another person, or no one). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked analyses including whole-brain results and coordinate tables (main effects, contrasts, conjunction analyses; Tables S1–S4; Figures showing parametric PE maps). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and does not include only clinical/special groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI during an explicitly social task (reappraisal of angry faces). Sample consists of healthy adults (N=60; age range 18–57), within the 17–65 criterion. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and reports coordinates and cluster tables (e.g., Observe-angry > Increase+Decrease, Decrease > Observe-angry), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and healthy-group results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (self-reference vs other-reference) in a healthy adult sample (N=110, age 19–31). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate GLM results (contrasts: SR+OR > baseline, self > other, other > self) with FWE-corrected inference and peak coordinates, satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from healthy adults. Although DCM effective connectivity analyses are included, the article also provides univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=34, mean age 22.2). The task involved naturalistic movie viewing emphasizing social interactions and mentalizing, which is directly relevant to social cognition constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise reverse-correlation analyses (including χ2 tests and cortical maps; Fig. 3) in addition to ROI results, providing univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Participants are within the 17–65 age range, and results for healthy controls are reported separately. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion/public performance evaluation) in healthy adults (20 men, 20 women; mean age 27.8, within 17–65). The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts using SPM8 (e.g., EX > IN, PG EX > FG EX), with voxelwise FWE-corrected thresholds and tables of peak MNI coordinates and conjunction analyses. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses and healthy-group task effects are clearly reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; not between-group-only; empirical original fMRI data). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of Theory-of-Mind/social cognition in healthy adults (N=19, ages 20–53). The task (REMICS) manipulates social vs. physical scenarios and contextual adjustment, addressing social-related processing. Results include group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (second-level random-effects one-sample t-tests) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction; multiple contrasts and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 3–6) are reported. The healthy/control group results are reported separately (no ROI-only or connectivity-only limitation; not restricted to between-group contrasts). Participants fall within the 17–65 range and analyses are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (impression updating/perception of others) in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–31). The task is social (evaluating others’ moral and behavioral information). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., L2>F3 main effect and condition interactions) with cluster-based correction and tables of coordinates (Tables and figures provided), not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy sample are reported. No exclusion criteria (e.g., patient-only sample, ROI-only, resting-state only, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: participants (final N=18, mean age 23.7, within 17–65) completed a social inference task while scanned. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task analyses (value and prediction-error regressors) with SPM, including tables of coordinates and conjunction and contrast maps across conditions. The study therefore satisfies: (1) task-based fMRI on social-related processing, (2) healthy adult sample reported separately, and (3) whole-brain voxelwise group results. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not non-empirical).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation), directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Self. Sample: healthy adults (final N=31, ages 19–24), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (multiple contrasts, whole-brain regression with self-esteem as regressor) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction (voxel-wise p<0.001, cluster-level p<0.05 FWE). It is not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind) in healthy adults (final N=18, ages 21–38). The paper reports group-level whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., coop_active > coop_passive; comp_active > comp_passive) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables/coordinates/figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy group. The task clearly probes social processes (cooperation vs. competition). The sample is within the 17–65 range and results for the healthy participants are reported. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (N=178; mean age 40.9, within 17–65). It uses a social-cognition task (EmpaToM) manipulating empathy and Theory-of-Mind and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (emotional vs neutral videos; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) with random-effects one-sample t-tests and activation peak tables/figures. Whole-brain task-evoked maps/results for the healthy/control group are clearly described and generalizable. The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing) using an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma task in healthy adults (n=163 for fMRI; ages 19–35). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (ment > cont) for the healthy sample, with cluster- and FWE-corrected results, tables of coordinates, and whole-brain maps. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. The healthy-group task activation map is clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state only, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation) in healthy adults (female sample, ages 22–32). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look; Self-Reg contrasts), with cluster-wise FWE-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates and figures. It is not an ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state-only study, and the healthy-group task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 24) using task-evoked paradigms that manipulate social-related processing (meaning-related vs physical-property judgments; own vs other; collective vs individual). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Meaning > Physical; Own > Other; interaction effects) with peak coordinates in Table 1 and statistical correction (FDR/FWE) described in the methods. Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Healthy adult results are reported separately and are generalizable to the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, out-of-range age group, clinical-only sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (visual social judgment of dominance/trustworthiness) conducted in a sample of healthy adults (N=23, ages 21–43). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment) with FWE-corrected cluster results and tables/figures describing activated clusters (DMPFC/dACC, bilateral DLPFC, AI, ventral visual cortex, etc.). Results are presented for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, task-based fMRI (not resting-state, connectivity-only, or ROI-only) and reports whole-brain statistical maps and coordinates. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind/social cognition in healthy adults (n=24, ages within 17–65). The task is a social-related story/prediction paradigm engaging perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate random-effects analyses and presents peak coordinates and cluster statistics (e.g., whole-brain contrasts for the ToM localizer and Outcome/Background segments with voxelwise and cluster-wise thresholds), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is empirical, task-based fMRI (not resting-state, connectivity-only, ROI-only, or between-group-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (race perception and trustworthiness evaluations), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=30; ages 18–29). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (e.g., Black > White contrasts) with voxelwise thresholds and tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2 and 3) and describes whole-brain covariate analyses; these results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Although the study also reports PPI connectivity, it additionally provides univariate whole-brain activation maps and coordinate tables, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social-evaluative processing in healthy adults (N=37, mean age 24.8 within 17–65). The task involves social-related constructs (social evaluation/mentalizing) using naturalistic video stimuli. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (negative > neutral, positive > neutral) with whole-brain FWE-corrected results presented in figures and tables, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy participant results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain activation maps are provided, and no exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI or only connectivity/resting-state analyses; non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (receiving emotionally and cognitively empathic vs. unempathic comments after negative performance feedback) in a healthy adult sample (N=20, mean age 26). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., EE>EN, CE>CN, negative>positive feedback) with tables of peak coordinates and FWE-corrected cluster results (see Tables 2–4 and associated figures). Analyses are within the healthy control group; results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. All key inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult group, whole-brain univariate maps reported) are met and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (a social cognition task) in healthy adult participants (n=21 included in analyses; mean age 23.7, right-handed). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., EFE > no EFE, no EFE > EFE, interaction effects) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level inference; a priori ROI amygdala tests are present but are accompanied by whole-brain results. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control sample and generalizable within the adult range (17–65). The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI task probing social processing (learning about others’ generosity — perception/understanding of others). (2) Healthy adult sample reported (final N=26; ages 19–37). (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (main effects and parametric contrasts), with cluster-correction and tables of peak coordinates; results are clearly from the healthy group. (4) Not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about others’ mental states) in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 18–27). The task is social-related (judging scenarios that evoke specific mental states). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain analyses: multivariate (searchlight MVPA) and parallel univariate whole-brain mapping with cluster-corrected results and tables of coordinates (Tables S2/S3, Figs. 2–4, S4). It is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction/communication (mentalizing) in healthy adults (final N=29, ages 18–27). The task manipulated perceived live vs recorded speech and probes social cognition; analyses focused on the story (speech) portion with whole-brain, group-level univariate contrasts (Live Story > Social Story; Social > Standard), thresholded and cluster-corrected and reported in text, tables, and figures. A subset completed an independent mentalizing localizer and individual ROIs were derived, but the paper clearly reports whole-brain task-evoked group results for the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy/compassion) using task-evoked stimuli (empathy-evoking film clips with contextual and musical manipulations). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=26, mean age 30.3), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts and statistical maps (mixed 2×3 ANOVA, contrasts for sad vs neutral context, multisensory > unisensory) with tables and FWE-corrected cluster results (Tables 1–2, Figure 3), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also includes DCM effective connectivity analyses, it additionally provides the required whole-brain activation maps for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants using a social task (viewing faces within real-world social networks to track popularity). The paper reports group-level task-evoked neural activity in valuation and social-cognition systems and describes whole-brain analyses (with results described in text, figures, and supporting information), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Participants are healthy adults (college-aged social networks), and results are presented for the healthy/group sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (explicit control of interpersonal trust/distrust) in healthy adults (n=60; mean age ~20), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., trust > age, distrust > age, attitude > age) with FWE-corrected whole-brain results presented in tables and figures. Healthy-group results are reported and generalizable (not limited to a narrow subgroup). The study includes complementary ROI analyses and exploratory connectivity but does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an empirical fMRI study of social gesture processing in healthy participants and reports group-level whole-brain task activation maps (cluster-corrected results and coordinate tables), the sample age range reported is 16.9–25.7 years. The review's inclusion criterion requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65 and/or a separately analyzed adult subgroup. The paper does not report a separate analysis limited to participants ≥17 years, and includes at least one participant below the 17-year threshold. Because the age criterion is not satisfied, the study must be excluded despite meeting other eligibility requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI hyperscanning study in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~21–23, within 17–65). It investigators social processes (mutual gaze and joint attention) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activations and contrasts (IJA, RJA, MG1/MG2, MG2–MG1), with tables of significant clusters and FWE-corrected results. Results are presented as voxelwise whole-brain statistics (tables/figures) generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and does not report only between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during a social-related task (passive viewing of in-group vs out-group facial expressions/disgust — perception and understanding of others). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (final N=26, mean age ~21.2, within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain evidence: group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses reported (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA, cluster-corrected results, reported coordinates and tables, e.g., Table 1 and whole-brain contrasts including the interaction ((disgusted out-group − neutral out-group) − (disgusted in-group − neutral in-group))). The paper also reports ROI and PPI analyses, but importantly includes univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy age group, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore INCLUDE.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Chinese university students, mean age ~20) using a social task (Cyberball social exclusion). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (exclusion vs inclusion) with tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected thresholds (e.g., Table 3 across all participants) and additionally reports ROI and PPI results. The healthy-group whole-brain activation map is clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=26; ages 19–26) that uses a task manipulating social vs non-social content while reading. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects contrasts (Social>Non-social and Vivid>Abstract) with cluster-corrected results and tables of peak coordinates, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps from the healthy group. Although ROI analyses are also used, whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly described. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only samples) are violated. Therefore the study should be included for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=30, ages 18–35). The task probes social-related processing (empathy for others’ pain; group membership effects), which fits constructs of perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8 ANOVA) with FWE-corrected main effects and interaction results, tables of coordinates, and cluster-level statistics—i.e., whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult subgroup reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=28, ages 18–29) using a social task (gaze-following to political personages) addressing social attention and social processing. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task contrasts (incongruent > congruent), with tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level corrected results, and describes whole-brain activation maps (FEF, parietal, insula, cingulate, occipital). Analyses for healthy/control participants are explicit and generalizable to healthy adults. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or patient-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task-based empirical study (EmpaToM) probing social cognition (empathy and Theory of Mind) in healthy adults. Samples include healthy adult participants (Experiment 2: N=178, mean age 40.9; Experiment 1a/b: adults), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., emotionally negative > neutral; ToM > nonToM) with coordinate tables and FWE-corrected thresholds and cluster sizes, suitable for meta-analysis. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and presents healthy-group univariate activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-reputation processing in healthy adults: 28 healthy, right-handed young volunteers (14 male, 14 female), ages 20–24. The task is explicitly social (receiving positive/negative reputation from others) and fits the review’s scope (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses with standard voxelwise thresholds (p<0.001 uncorrected; cluster-level FWE p<0.05) and provides peak coordinates and cluster sizes in Table 1, as well as whole-brain contrast images (e.g., positive vs neutral, negative vs neutral, conjunction, and (positive>neutral) vs (negative>neutral)). Results are presented for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults (age within 17–65). The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes original empirical fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: Empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (viewing social vs non-social scenes) in healthy adult participants (final N=33, ages 18–21). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results (social > non-social contrast) with FDR-corrected, random-effects analyses and tables of MNI coordinates (i.e., whole-brain statistical map results are clearly reported). The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity, resting-state, between-group-only contrasts, nor is it a review. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of healthy adult fMRI studies of social processing.

This is an empirical fMRI study of action understanding that explicitly examines social-cognitive processing (why/how distinctions, mentalizing/theory-of-mind network). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=17 after exclusions; ages 21–46) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (ROI and whole-brain analyses; cluster-forming threshold P<0.001 with cluster-level FWE correction; Supplementary Tables and NeuroVault maps referenced). Task is an event-related why/how social-cognition task; healthy-group results are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25, mean age 21.6) that explicitly manipulates social cognitive content (social working memory task) during task-based fMRI. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses (parametric modulation, conjunction and contrasts) with cluster/voxel thresholds and tables/figures of activated regions (mentalizing and lateral frontoparietal systems). Results are presented for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to healthy adults (age within 17–65). The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked social processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI investigating social-related processing (social incentive delay task with social reward faces); (2) Sample includes healthy adult participants (N=63, ages ~20.4–36.6) with results reported for this healthy group; (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (multiple whole-brain FWE-corrected contrasts and tables of coordinates for reward>neutral, social>monetary, feedback contrasts; Tables 2–4 and whole-brain analyses described); (4) Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=41, mean age 22.6, within 17–65) using a social-affective mimicry task probing affiliation-related processing. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain univariate contrasts (Incongruent>Congruent and masked interaction contrasts) with full reporting of cluster results and MNI coordinates (Tables 2–4) and corrected multiple-comparison inference. The task is social (affiliation, perception of others) and results are reported for the healthy control sample separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (social vs. nonsocial attribution; why/how task) in healthy adults (N=19, ages 21–46). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (why > how) with conjunction and interaction whole-brain analyses, cluster-level family-wise error correction, and tables/coordinates of activation (e.g., Table 2, whole-brain conjunction results; NeuroVault and supplemental materials available). Results for the healthy participant group are reported independently; the sample falls within the 17–65 age range. The paper includes whole-brain activation maps and coordinate tables rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The paper reports task-based fMRI hyperscanning in healthy adult dyads using a joint-attention paradigm and meets sample and task-domain criteria. However, it does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (e.g., GLM main effect or within-group contrast). Analyses are based on group ICA spatial components and cross-brain coupling/permutation tests rather than voxelwise task activation maps for the healthy group. Because the review requires at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map from the healthy/control group, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (prediction of others’ behavior, theory-of-mind and deontic reasoning). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–44) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses with tables of coordinates and cluster-corrected results (see Tables 2 and 3 and whole-brain maps described), and also reports small-volume corrections for regions of interest; it is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within the required age range). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (crowd emotion and interaction) in healthy adults (N=16, ages 19–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate analyses (random-effects ANOVAs) with cluster-corrected voxelwise results presented in tables and figures (Tables 1–3, whole-brain maps). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others’ emotions and interactions). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI investigating social-related processing (perception of person interactions) during an explicit sex-categorization task while viewing social dyads. (2) Sample comprises healthy adults (n=12; ages 21–31), within 17–65. (3) Reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses and contrasts for the healthy participant group (voxelwise p<.001, cluster-based p<.05); whole-brain results are tabulated and illustrated (Table 3, Figures 6–7). Not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (body orientation and co-speech gesture) in healthy adults (N=37, mean age 25, range 20–39), fitting the target population (17–65). The experiment used a task-based design requiring addressment judgments and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts (main effects and interactions) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics. Results are presented for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The paper is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=13, mean age 24.85) that implements a social-interaction (joint attention) task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., RJA - RJAc, IJA - IJAc), presents thresholded statistical maps and tables of activation coordinates, and uses whole-brain FDR correction. The task and contrasts clearly target social processing (joint attention, representation of self/other attention). Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses, and healthy adult findings are reported separately and generalizable to the target population. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults: participants (N=18, age 19–28) received text messages they believed came from a friend or a computer. It addresses social-related processing (social communication/mentalizing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g. friend minus computer) with voxelwise statistical maps and cluster tables (Table 2 and SPM figures showing dmPFC, precuneus, TPJ, temporal poles). Results are clearly reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable within the healthy adult sample. Although additional MVPA/MVCA analyses are included, the study provides univariate whole-brain activation maps, satisfying the inclusion criteria. Sample falls within the 17–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults: 50 healthy participants aged 18–29 performed an explicit social task (labeling emotional facial expressions — perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (HA>NE, AN>NE, FE>NE) with cluster-level FWE-corrected results, peak coordinates, and tables of activation — i.e., whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps for the healthy sample. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, clinical groups, or non-empirical work. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults (voice–face identity recognition) with group-level random-effects analyses, the reported task results are restricted to region-of-interest (small-volume/ROI-corrected) activity and PPI connectivity. The paper does not present or describe an unmasked, whole-brain group-level univariate task activation map (nor whole-brain corrected peaks); significant effects are reported only after ROI/SVC correction. According to the review’s inclusion criteria, at least one group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical map (generalizable to healthy adults) must be reported. Because the study reports only ROI-focused results and connectivity analyses without accompanying whole-brain task activation maps, it fails the whole-brain evidence criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of implicit and explicit theory-of-mind (social cognition) using task-based 'Sally–Anne' movies. Participants were healthy adults (initial N=20; behavioral N=18; MRI analyses N=16), mean age 22.7 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects GLM contrasts (e.g., explicit belief > photo/map), with cluster thresholds and Talairach coordinates provided, and displays whole-brain SPMs for task contrasts. Analyses are univariate, task-evoked, and clearly from the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or only between-group contrasts) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (impression formation/perception of others varying in moral and financial status). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=20 males, ages 19–31) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (exploratory whole-brain ANOVA and Table 1 listing voxel coordinates and clusters), in addition to ROI results, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy group. The task and contrasts are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI-only analyses, resting-state/connectivity-only, clinical-only sample, or non-empirical paper) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants (healthy adults, N=16, age 18–25) performed a social competitive task (matching-pennies) after brief social interactions with various agents. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (GLM, random-effects second-level one-sample t-tests) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides MNI coordinates/tables of activations (Tables 2–3) and brain maps. All inclusion criteria are met: task is social, sample is healthy adults within age range, and whole-brain task-evoked activation maps for the healthy group are reported. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not patient-only, empirical original data). Therefore the study should be included.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (reactivity to angry facial expressions in an interactive Taylor Aggression Paradigm). Sample: healthy adult participants (32 included in analyses; mean age 23.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (angry > neutral) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables/figures of activations (decision and outcome phases; Tables 1 & 2, whole-brain results described in text). Results for healthy participants are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. Analyses include whole-brain and ROI checks, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (n=19, mean age 26.5). The task explicitly probes social cognition (imagining triadic interactions; self- and other-referential conditions), fitting constructs of perception/understanding of self and others. Group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and conjunctions are reported (e.g., triad > iron, triad > (self & other), conjunction analyses) with family-wise error correction and tables of MNI coordinates, fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy adult sample results are reported separately and not limited to a special subgroup. The study is empirical and provides task-evoked whole-brain activation maps; it does not rely solely on ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ten right-handed males, ages 22–32) that investigates perception/understanding of others’ social interactions using point-light biological-motion stimuli — a social-related construct. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., (atypical > typical) with voxelwise statistics, cluster-size correction, Talairach coordinates and tables), not solely ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable (within limits) to healthy adults. Although sample size is small (N=10) and only males were scanned, all inclusion criteria are met (healthy adults, social task, whole-brain group-level maps reported). Thus the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=20, mean age 24.6) using a social-related task (viewing first-person video clips of neutral, social-positive, and reactive-aggressive interactions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and conjunctions (tables of peak coordinates and whole-brain FDR-corrected results for contrasts such as reactive-aggressive vs. neutral, social-positive vs. neutral, and direct contrasts between affective conditions). Results are presented as voxelwise activation maps summarized in tables/figures (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an original, task-based fMRI study of social interaction (interactive emotion alignment) in healthy adults (n=20; mean age 23.95). The experiment examines social-related processes (social appraisal/conformity/empathy) and uses whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate analyses reported with clusterwise FWE correction; results are presented in tables/figures (e.g., activations in anterior insula, ventral striatum, amygdala). The paper is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and reports within-group task-evoked whole-brain effects generalizable to a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (self-referential processing during intergroup competition) in healthy adults (final N=21, Mage=23.1). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (Tables 1 and 2; whole-brain corrected results and cluster coordinates are provided; SnPM corrections and random-effects analyses are described). The task engages social constructs (perception/understanding of self and intergroup social cognition). Participants fall within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy sample are reported clearly and generalizable. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion, punishment and forgiveness) in healthy adults (N=26; mean age 20.7, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Excluders > Includers; Excluders equality > Includers equality; exclusion no-ball > inclusion ball) with tables of coordinates and FDR-corrected results. Analyses are based on a healthy participant group and results are generalizable to healthy adults. The study includes whole-brain results (not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses) and therefore meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=20, ages 18–41), using a social/mentalizing causal-attribution task (self, other, situation). Group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses are reported (ANOVA and contrasts vs. baseline), with voxelwise results and coordinates presented in Table 1 and conjunction/contrast maps; results are described as random-effects group analyses and thresholded with FWE correction. The healthy/control group results are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-groups-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=17, ages 18–27) using a social task (witnessing an emergency/bystander scenarios) that probes perception and action-related social processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (parametric effects of group size and several contrasts) with statistical maps and tables of Talairach coordinates (Tables 1–3) and corrected cluster thresholds. It is not an ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only study, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task fMRI with social stimuli in healthy participants, the fMRI results are reported primarily from predefined ROIs (beta-weight extractions and ROI-based GLMs). The paper does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy adult group; reported fMRI effects are ROI-constrained. In addition, the sample mixes adolescents (12–18) and adults (19–30) and does not report a separate whole-brain analysis restricted to an adult-only (17–65) group. Therefore it fails the review’s requirement for whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group maps (and does not clearly provide adult-only whole-brain results).

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (subset N=22, mean age ~18.9) using a face-versus-house face perception task (a social-related stimulus: perception/understanding of others). The paper describes SPM8 second-level, group-level univariate analyses and reports whole-brain group activation (significant clusters reported in Table 2 and Figure 3/4; faces versus houses contrast; FWE-corrected results are presented). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps/cluster coordinates; it fits all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of online social interaction (reciprocal imitation), a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Sample: 23 healthy right-handed adults (females), ages 18–30, meeting the 17–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked GLM results (contrasts imitating, being imitated, observation vs rest) with familywise-error corrected maps and coordinates in tables/figures. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the study also provides univariate whole-brain activation maps for the healthy adult group. It is empirical original fMRI research in healthy adults and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and reports unmasked healthy-group task effects). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI comparing neural responses to familiar (partner, child, friend) versus unfamiliar faces, which maps onto social cognition (perception/understanding of others/attachment). It includes a healthy control group (n=13) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts for the control group with voxelwise results and coordinates (FWE-corrected clusters and tables), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although participants are described as 'older' (mean age 64.5 ±5.7), the sample falls within the adult range targeted by the review and healthy-group results are reported separately from the clinical case. Therefore the paper meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related, task-based fMRI study of social decision-making (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) probing perception/understanding of others, trust, and cooperation—constructs clearly within social-related processing. Sample comprises healthy adults (n≈35 after exclusions; mean age 24.6 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise GLM results (contrasts, cluster-size correction) with tables/figures of significant clusters (TPJ, precuneus, medial PFC, etc.), not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are explicitly described and generalized. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study is an original fMRI experiment of social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=15 males, ages 21–40). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain analyses (random-effects ANOVA, voxelwise thresholds, cluster correction) with coordinates and tables/figures of activations for within-group contrasts (e.g., empathy vs ToM, sad vs neutral), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and not limited to between-group contrasts. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of explicit social judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) on vocal stimuli in 44 healthy right-handed adults (age range 21–60), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., (TR–HA)∩(AT–AG)) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides tables/figures of voxelwise activations. It is an empirical task-based fMRI study (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only) and reports results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports original fMRI data in healthy adult participants (22 right-handed women, mean age 27.2). The task is social communication (live verbal interaction), directly relevant to the review objective. The analyses include group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise second-level t-tests for talking, listening and imagining, with cluster-corrected thresholds and reported significant clusters (figures/tables provided). This is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only. Results for the healthy group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports voxel-based morphometry (structural MRI) correlates of proneness to moral sentiments in healthy adults, not primary task-based fMRI activation results. Although a subgroup previously participated in an earlier fMRI study and the authors used SSC-BOLD peak values from that prior work as covariates, the current article does not present a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked activation map from healthy participants. Therefore it fails the review’s required inclusion criterion of reporting at least one healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. Other criteria (healthy adult sample, social task relevance) are met, but lack of reported whole-brain fMRI task maps mandates exclusion.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=32, mean age ~24.7) that used a social task manipulating collaboration vs competition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM results, clusterwise FWE-corrected activations and coordinate tables) linking social-context parametric modulators (personal utility, collaboration, competition, social position) to brain activity (e.g., ventral basal ganglia, TPJ, mPFC). Results for the healthy sample are reported and generalizable; analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only approaches. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.
