This is an event-related fMRI study using a Dynamic Social Gesture task that directly probes social-related processing (social vs. nonsocial gestures, actor-orientation, face-visibility). Sample: 20 healthy adults (mean age 21.41, range 16.9–25.7) — overwhelmingly within the adult range; although one participant is 16.9, the group is reported as a healthy adult sample and results are presented at the group level. Whole-brain, univariate group-level task activation maps are reported (TFCE with permutation testing; tables/figures of activations described), not ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, only between-group contrasts, non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria. Note: borderline single participant age (16.9) is acknowledged but does not materially alter that the reported group-level healthy adult results are generalizable to adults 17–65.

The paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants performing a social-affective (empathy / emotional egocentricity) task. Participant groups are healthy adults (female undergraduates) with fMRI samples (N=18 and N=32) and behavioral samples. Group-level, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts are reported (interaction contrast [(other incongruent > congruent) > (self incongruent > congruent)]), with MNI coordinates and tables; authors performed random-effects analyses and report whole-brain results (and SVC constrained by independent localizer). The study therefore provides univariate, group-level whole-brain activation maps derived from healthy adults during a social cognitive task, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (male, ages 19–30) that used a social-related task (viewing traffic-awareness videos eliciting mentalizing/empathy and social-cognitive processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (campaign videos vs neutral videos) for the healthy driver groups, with whole-brain analyses, figures, and tables of significant clusters (in addition to ROI analyses). It therefore meets the fMRI social-processing task criterion, the healthy adult sample criterion (ages within 17–65), and the requirement for whole-brain, group-level task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply. Included for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (sample ages 19–28; N=45 with 31–35 included in analyses). Tasks are social-related (implicit/explicit detection of eye-gaze shifts and self-propelling motion; implicit mental-inference role-playing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests, contrasts E–O and S–X, PCA-derived regressions) with tables of activation peaks/coordinates and cluster-corrected thresholds. Results are presented as voxelwise contrasts and coordinates (Tables 3–4, Figures), not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults studying social processing.

This is an empirical fMRI study (NeuroImage, 2013) that examined impression formation about real people using task-evoked BOLD in healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 19.1). The task is social (perception/understanding of others) and includes event-related whole-brain univariate GLM analyses: a functional localizer contrast (form impression > remember order) and main 2×2 (outcome-dependency × expectancy-consistency) ANOVA, with reported group-level voxelwise results (Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, cluster-corrected thresholds) and tables of coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy control group and are generalizable to healthy adults in the specified age range. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of nonverbal social interaction perception in healthy adults (n=21 males, age 23–33). The task probes social communication/perception (ratings of naturalness of dyadic interactions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., meaningful > scrambled; contingency and fluency main effects; interaction), random-effects analyses, and tables of peak coordinates and cluster-level corrected results. Results for the healthy control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=46 females, age 18–31) using social cognition tasks (theory-of-mind/emotion/pain judgments). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., B>Ph, E>Ph, Pa>Ph) with cluster-corrected results, tables of coordinates, and figures—satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. The sample falls within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy control group (no reliance solely on ROIs, connectivity-only analyses, or between-group contrasts). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (recognition of others’ ‘vitality forms’ — perception/understanding of others). Sample: 19 healthy adult participants (ages reported 21–29), within review age range (17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., what vs how; how vs what) with cluster- and voxel-level PFWE-corrected results, tables of MNI coordinates, and figures — satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although ROI analyses are included, they do not replace whole-brain results. The study does not rely solely on connectivity, ROI-only, or between-group contrasts, and is not a review. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (N=31, ages 18–26). The task is social-related (gambling for self, best friend, or antagonist) probing affiliation/other-processing. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses (repeated-measures ANOVAs) with coordinates and tables (Tables 1–2) and reports FDR/FWE-corrected clusters (ventral striatum, mPFC, TPJ, precuneus), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes no clinical-only group, and is empirical with original fMRI data. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (compassion/empathy regulation) in healthy adult participants (ages 18–45). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (suffering vs neutral; training-induced pre/post changes) and corrected whole-brain results identifying right IPC and DLPFC, as well as ROI-corrected PPI results (NAcc). The sample is healthy adults and results are reported at the group level and generalizable to healthy adults. The study therefore meets the inclusion criteria (task-evoked fMRI during social-related processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate voxelwise results). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or absence of healthy-group whole-brain maps) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social communicative gesture processing in healthy adults (n=20 reported; right-handed males, mean age 24.6). The task explicitly probes social communication/communicative intention (observation and imitation of social vs non-social vs meaningless gestures). Group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts and interaction effects are reported (e.g., IMI>CT conjunction, S>NS main effects, interaction maps) with MNI coordinates and Monte-Carlo whole-brain correction; results are presented in tables and figures. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, healthy adult sample within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI evidence in healthy adults investigating social processing.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (communicative vs private intentions) in a sample of healthy adults (n=23, mean age 24 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., CInt > PInt) with peak coordinates and tables of activations (MNI coordinates, Z-values) and thresholding details, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the paper also reports PPI connectivity, it additionally provides univariate voxelwise task activations for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants are within the age range). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (learning from romantic interest/rejection) in healthy adults. Scanned sample: N=38 healthy adults, ages 19–31 (within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Yes>No, Mismatch>Match, Match>Unrequited) with tables of peak coordinates and thresholding details, and figures showing activations (VMPFC, RMPFC, pSTS, etc.). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages, or only between-group contrasts) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing about groups and individuals). Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range (Experiment 1: N=25, ages 19–27; Experiment 2: N=14, ages 18–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate contrasts (e.g., group mental > group physical, member mental > member physical, individual mental > individual physical) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster extents, and tables of MNI coordinates (whole-brain results corrected for multiple comparisons). The task and contrasts clearly index social-related processing (theory of mind/mentalizing). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy-group whole-brain task maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (comparative judgments of physical attractiveness/beauty, and height) in healthy adult participants (25 right-handed British women; mean age 23.5 years within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANOVA, conjunctions, whole-brain maps, and tables of MNI coordinates) and thresholding information; results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain results are primary and clearly described. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–27) that investigates social-cognitive constructs (action identification/mentalizing, abstraction vs. concretization) relevant to perception and understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task contrasts (e.g., How > Why, Exemplars > Categories, conjunctions) with statistical thresholds and cluster-corrected results, and provides coordinate tables and figures (Table 2, Figure 1). Analyses are generalizable to a healthy adult sample and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=17, mean age 23.5) that investigates social processing (interpersonal resource conflict). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (e.g., Conflict > No Conflict, Human (Conflict>No Conflict) > Computer (Conflict>No Conflict)) using random-effects second-level analyses, with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics and thresholding described. The task explicitly probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social decision-making), and results for the healthy adult sample are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and is empirical with original fMRI data. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/perception of others’ pain) in healthy adult participants (N≈36, mean age ~21, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (painful vs non-painful stimuli) with FDR-corrected results and tables of MNI coordinates (see Table 3 and whole-brain analyses described for pre- and post-priming sessions). The analyses are not limited to ROI-only, nor to resting-state or connectivity-only results; whole-brain maps are clearly described and generalizable to a healthy adult population. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (initial N=16, final imaging N=14, mean age 22 within 17–65) using a social-related task (trustworthiness judgments of faces) contrasted with a nonsocial control. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (2×2 repeated-measures ANOVA), with cluster-corrected thresholds and tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes for main effects and interactions, demonstrating univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group. Analyses are not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and results are reported for the healthy sample. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of visual perspective taking/theory-of-mind in healthy adult participants (N=16, mean age 22.4), using a task manipulating self vs. other perspectives. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8), provides coordinate tables and cluster-level FWE correction, and describes multiple whole-brain contrasts (e.g., Inconsistent Other > Consistent Other) that are generalizable to the healthy adult group. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and results for healthy controls are reported separately. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, not patient-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly includes social cognition tasks (theory-of-mind/social videos and social texts) administered to a group of healthy adult participants (N=45, ages 19–23). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (social > mechanical, mechanical > social) with strict conjunction and random-effects analyses, provides voxelwise results/figures and peak coordinates (Appendix A), and compares task activations to resting-state anti-correlations. The healthy control group results are reported and generalizable (random-effects). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perspective taking/empathy) in healthy adults (n=18; ages 21–31). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM8), including paired t-tests and conjunction analyses with FWE correction across the whole brain; results are provided as tables of coordinates and figures. Although some contrasts used small-volume correction for predefined ROIs, whole-brain effects and cluster-/peak-level FWE-corrected results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not a review, and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, resting-state, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study is an empirical fMRI investigation of affiliative social processing in healthy adults (final N=27, mean age ~27, within 17–65). The task explicitly probes affiliation/attachment using written kinship-related scenarios. The paper reports group-level, univariate, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (e.g., affiliative vs nonaffiliative; reported survivals at whole-brain FWE-corrected p<0.05 and tabulated coordinates in Table 2 and figures). Results are presented as generalizable healthy-group task activations rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=17 males, mean age 23.6) using social-motive film clips (affiliation/romantic love and power) — a social-related task. Group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses are reported (contrasts affiliation>control and power>control) with cluster coordinates and corrected p-values (Table 1, figures) and regression of contrasts on motive scores, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps for a healthy adult sample. The paper presents original empirical fMRI data and is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only, pediatric/elderly-only, or non-empirical analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (learning to simulate others’ decisions) in healthy adult participants (36 subjects after exclusions). The task explicitly probes perception/understanding of others (prediction of another person’s choices), fitting the review’s social-related constructs. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked statistical maps and peak coordinates (Tables 1–2) with cluster-level corrected p-values and figures showing voxelwise activations (vmPFC, dmPFC, dlPFC, TPJ/pSTS, etc.). Analyses are within healthy adults and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults and should be included.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=94 women, ages 18–35) using a social-affective task (Socio-Affective Video Task) probing responses to others’ distress (empathy/compassion/affiliation). The paper reports group-level, univariate task-evoked whole-brain analyses (HE vs LE contrasts and parametric modulations) with family-wise-error corrected results and coordinate tables/figures mapping activations (e.g., AI, aMCC, mOFC, striatum). Results are reported for the healthy participant sample (within- and across-group contrasts) and are generalizable to healthy adults rather than a narrowly defined clinical subgroup. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level maps) and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and presents whole-brain task activation maps).

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults using naturalistic, task-based movie viewing that probes social/emotional processing relevant to perception/understanding of others and social interaction. The paper reports multisubject voxelwise intersubject correlation (ISC) analyses and voxelwise ISC predicted by valence and arousal (group-level, whole-brain effects), and presents seed-voxel correlation analyses supporting network-level findings. Results are reported at the whole-brain voxel level (maps/analyses generalizable to healthy adults) rather than only ROI or resting-state/connectivity-only contrasts. Therefore it meets the review’s task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain evidence inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/self-other representation) in healthy adults (n=22, mean age 23.6). The paper reports task-evoked whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (threat minus safe contrasts), conjunction analyses and whole-brain higher-level comparisons, with cluster thresholds and coordinate tables; supplementary whole-brain results are also referenced. Although ROI analyses are used, unmasked group-level whole-brain activation maps and contrasts are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective speech comprehension that probes social-cognitive processes (theory-of-mind/inferring others' emotions). Participants: 51 healthy adults (ages 18–53), within required 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (EMO vs GRAM contrasts, SPM results, FWE-corrected maps and activation tables/figures), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Results are clearly from the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, not only between-group contrasts). Therefore the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation/updating) in healthy adults (N=24; ages 18–45). The task is social (faces paired with valenced behaviors). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses (interaction and L2>F3 contrasts) with thresholding and cluster tables/figures, not ROI-only results. Healthy adult group results are reported separately and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not resting-state, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults and should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study of empathic decision-making (social cognition: empathy/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (N=32 males, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (GLM1–4) with whole-brain cluster-level correction and tables/figures of activations; vmPFC results also reported with small-volume correction but multiple whole-brain contrasts and coordinate tables are provided. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only (although PPI is included, whole-brain task maps are present). Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results are reported for the healthy group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (a social working memory/mentalizing task) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 20, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (parametric load regressors during delay and probe periods) with coordinates and cluster thresholds (Tables S2/S3, whole-brain maps and figures). Results are presented for the healthy participant group (no exclusive ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only reporting). Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=13, mean age 28.2) using a social-related perceptual task (biological motion / point-light walkers probing perception/understanding of others’ actions). It presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (canonical vs scrambled biological motion) with corrected statistical maps and tables of MNI coordinates. Although the paper also includes connectivity/DCM analyses, it clearly provides an univariate, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map, meeting all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=14, mean age 35.9) using a social competition paradigm (human vs. machine) that manipulates Theory of Mind/social interaction during a Stroop task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., I(H+M)>C(H+M); H(I+C)>M(I+C); interaction [H(I>C)]>[M(I>C)]) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics (Tables 2–4) and thresholding details (P<0.001 uncorrected, cluster size ≥5). Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, ages 18–34) using a social-related task (emotion classification from faces and voices — social communication/perception). The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (RFX-GLM) with voxelwise contrasts, conjunctions, and FDR-corrected results and tables of activation clusters, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 range). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants (age 19–28) performing social-related tasks (semantic judgments about social categories/stereotypes versus non-social categories). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise contrasts (e.g., ‘social>non-social’ and ‘non-social>social’) with correction for multiple comparisons (P<0.05 corrected) and tables/figures of peak coordinates. Analyses and results are reported for the healthy adult sample separately. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using a task that compares perceptions of close (romantic partner) and non-close (roommate) others — clearly a social-related task (affiliation/attachment; perception of others). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=20, mean age 18.7, ages within 17–65), screened for neurological/psychiatric conditions. The paper reports group-level, within-group univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Close Other > Non-Close Other; Positive > Negative; Target × Breadth interaction) analyzed at the second level (random effects) and presents peak coordinates and cluster statistics (FWE-corrected) for reported contrasts. Although ROI masks were used for multiple-comparison correction, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts and coordinates are reported and attributable to the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria (only ROI/ connectivity-only, clinical-only samples, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 23) that investigates social processing (eye contact and mimicry). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Congruent > Catch, Incongruent > Catch, Direct-Cong > Averted-Cong, interaction) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; results are reported in tables of coordinates and figures. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. Although the paper also includes DCM connectivity analyses, it clearly provides whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy adult sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of prosocial (social-related) decision-making toward family, engaging social-cognitive constructs (mentalizing, self-control). Sample: 25 healthy young adults (Mage=20.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts (Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of coordinates and corrected statistics (Tables 1–3; FDR/cluster thresholds), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, the study additionally provides univariate whole-brain task activation maps and coordinates for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (20 young adults) viewing dynamic social interaction videos, directly addressing social-related processing. The abstract states group-level whole-brain findings (significant right > left activation for positive and negative conditions in the amygdaloid complex, inferior frontal gyrus, fusiform gyrus, and temporal gyri, p < 0.0001), which constitutes univariate, task-evoked whole-brain results for the healthy group. The sample age fits the 17–65 range and results pertain to the healthy/control group. The paper is empirical and not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Although the full PDF is paywalled, the provided content clearly reports whole-brain group activations, meeting all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (representation of social interaction/social context vs self-generation) with a task manipulating social interaction during encoding and a recognition retrieval task; (2) Sample: 24 healthy right-handed adult participants aged 18–28 (within 17–65); (3) Reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise task contrasts and statistical maps/coordinates (tables and figures showing contrasts, thresholding, and MNI coordinates for right and left mPFC, MCC, etc.); (4) Results are reported for the healthy/control group and generalizable (random-effects, group-level analyses). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, and not a review). Therefore include.

The study is an empirical fMRI investigation of social perception (race-based impression formation) in healthy adults (N=44, ages 19–34). It uses a social-related task (impression formation of Black and White faces paired with valenced words) and reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (Tables 2 and 3; whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are provided, including an Incongruent vs. Congruent contrast and exploratory whole-brain regressions). Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, participants are within age range). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of humor processing (a form of social cognition involving perception/understanding of others and affective social processing) in a healthy adult sample (n=29, mean age 27, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (Cartoons vs Neutral; parametric modulation by funniness) with voxelwise results reported and corrected (FWE and Monte Carlo cluster correction) and peak coordinates in tables. Healthy-group effects are reported (separately for males/females and conjunctions across groups), and results are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (gaze-mediated stimulus-response compatibility) with healthy adult participants aged 21–37. The authors report whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses (second-level random-effects SPM analysis) including main effects and interactions (e.g., INC, SOC, OBJ, INC×SOC) thresholded at cluster-level corrected p<0.05 and presented in tables/figures. Results are clearly derived from the healthy/control sample and generalizable within the adult range. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an event-related fMRI study (n=64 healthy adults, age range 18–26) examining social cognition (mentalizing/understanding others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses identifying voxels/regions (MPFC, orbitofrontal cortex, etc.) whose BOLD response parametrically relates to self–other discrepancy, with peak coordinates and a table of whole-brain results. Healthy adult group results are reported separately and are generalizable. The study is empirical, task-based fMRI, not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state, and thus meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (recognition of personally familiar vs famous vs unfamiliar faces), which falls under Perception/Understanding of Others and social cognition. Sample: healthy adults (24 analyzed; ages 19–31), within the 17–65 range. Whole-brain, voxelwise, group-level univariate contrasts are reported (e.g., P1-Cp1, P2-Cp2, P1-F1, P2-F2) with statistical thresholds and cluster correction; results are presented in tables of coordinates and figures. The paper reports task-evoked activation maps for the healthy/control group and is not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study is an empirical fMRI investigation of social-related processing (social preference) in healthy adults (N=21, ages 23–51). It reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (Preference > Gender; Preference and Gender vs baseline) with statistical maps and tables of activation peaks (FDR-corrected whole-brain inference), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. Although it also includes PPI connectivity analyses, the paper clearly provides univariate whole-brain task activation results for the healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=36, mean age 23) investigating social-related processing (empathy, attachment/intimacy). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (Pain > Neutral and perspective contrasts) with voxelwise statistical maps and tables of coordinates (FDR-corrected thresholds reported). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses (although PPI is included, whole-brain activation maps are clearly presented). Participants fall within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group effects are reported and generalizable (random-effects analyses). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This paper (Redcay et al., 2010) reports task-based fMRI of social processing (live face-to-face interaction and joint attention) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1: N=16; Experiment 2: N=13; ages 18–29). It presents group-level, univariate whole-brain contrasts (e.g., Live > Recorded; Joint Attention > Solo Attention) with voxelwise results and coordinate tables, corrected for multiple comparisons. Analyses are not restricted to ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches, and the reported effects are clearly identified as coming from healthy/control participants. Thus all inclusion criteria are met for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (a social decision engaging empathy/perspective-taking), with 22 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.7) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., VMPFC activity correlated with donation value; pSTC correlated with willingness-to-give) with whole-brain corrections and coordinates. Results from healthy participants are reported separately and are generalizable. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain statistical maps/contrasts, satisfying all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (joint attention/representation of what another person sees) in healthy adults (usable N=12, ages 20–31). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts (body > place and place > body) with coordinate tables (Table 1) and whole-brain statistical maps described in the text and figures. Tasks and analyses are task-evoked (not resting-state or connectivity-only), and results are reported for the healthy/control group, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an original, task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=13 used; age range 19.4–31). The task examines social cognition (self- and other-referential trait judgments; perception/understanding of self and others). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts and SPM results (e.g., self>syllables, other>syllables, old/same>new) with coordinate tables and figures, not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Results are clearly reported for the healthy control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not resting-state, not ROI-only, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=16, mean age 27.8) investigating social cognition/empathy (emotion vs. neutral scenes; social relation two vs. one). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts with voxelwise results and peak Talairach coordinates (e.g., EMOT > NEUT, TWO > ONE), fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Analyses are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only methods, and results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Hence it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) in healthy adults (n=18, ages 20–45). The task is a naturalistic, video-based social cognition paradigm (MASC), and the paper reports group-level whole-brain, univariate GLM results (contrast maps and cluster coordinates reported in Table 1; thresholding and cluster-size correction described). Whole-brain model-free (T-PICA) results are also provided but the presence of GLM whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group satisfies the requirement. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore include.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=26; mean age 24.4) investigating perception/understanding of others’ pain and social context — a social cognition task directly relevant to the review objective. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (main effects of pain and social context, interaction) with tables of stereotactic coordinates and FDR-corrected thresholds, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Healthy adult results are reported separately and generalizable (not limited to a special subgroup). Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, univariate whole-brain task activations are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attachment/affiliation) using masked emotional face stimuli. Sample: 51 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 28.5, within 17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked results (main effects of masked sad/happy vs neutral and regression analyses of attachment avoidance on brain activation) with tables of coordinates and cluster statistics for a priori ROIs and whole-brain thresholds. Results are reported for the healthy sample specifically. The study does not rely solely on ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses and includes generalizable group-level activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=18 analyzed, ages 18–22). The task is social (Trust Game; reciprocity, perspective-taking) and addresses social processing constructs (perception/understanding of others, social decision-making). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., defect>reciprocate, reciprocate>defect) and regression analyses with coordinates and corrected thresholds (AlphaSim-corrected reporting; Table 1, figures), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately (participants were healthy volunteers). The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity/resting-state analyses and is within the 17–65 age range. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (Reading the Mind in the Eyes task) in healthy adult participants (right-handed native Japanese and white American adults, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., RME - gender discrimination), mixed-effects second-level analyses, and tables/coordinates of activations (bilateral pSTS, IFG, etc.), clearly generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group whole-brain task effects are explicitly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (face target detection) in healthy adults (N=19; age range 19.3–47.5), within the 17–65 inclusion range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., face targets > novels; shape targets > novels; direct comparison (face>shape) with cluster-corrected Z-thresholding using FSL FLAME and MNI coordinates in Table 2). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses and healthy-group effects are reported and generalizable to typical adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (gaze shifts/joint attention) in healthy adult participants (behavioral N=10, fMRI N=12; ages 18–41/18–40). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses using SPM (e.g., contrasts: gaze-shift vs no-movement, incorrect vs correct, social vs unsocial) with tables and figures of activation loci and cluster results. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes generalizable healthy-group task activation maps. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adult participants (N=18 undergraduates, mean age ~20). The task probes social processing (inferring vegetable preferences vs categorical age judgments), clearly within the review’s constructs (perception/understanding of others, mentalizing). Methods report whole-brain, voxelwise EPI analyses with random-effects group-level contrasts and reported coordinates/clusters (Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, tables and figures), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Results include univariate task-evoked whole-brain contrasts (task main effect and social-group main effect) generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI evidence of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This paper reports an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=10) performing a social perception task (viewing animated approaching characters displaying angry vs. happy expressions). The authors performed group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (Angry>Happy and Happy>Angry contrasts), report coordinates and cluster tables, and present univariate task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. It therefore meets inclusion criteria: fMRI during a social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level voxelwise results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range participants) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (initial N=20, final analyzed N=12, mean age 24.6) using social-content Wason selection tasks probing theory-of-mind/social-exchange vs precautionary reasoning. The paper reports group-level random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (story and card-phase contrasts), thresholding and cluster extents, and tables/figures of activations. Results for the healthy/control group are presented separately and are generalizable to healthy adults aged 17–65. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, resting-state, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mentalizing/theory-of-mind: attributing intentions to perceived musical compositions). Sample: healthy adults (n=12 included in analysis; ages 21–31), satisfying the age and healthy-sample criteria. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (Composer > Computer) with peak coordinates, Z-scores, cluster extents, and corrected thresholds; results are presented in tables and figures, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design is task-evoked (blocked listening task) rather than ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI study in 17 healthy adult volunteers (ages 20–34) performing social-communication tasks (gaze following and finger pointing). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (task vs baseline and between-condition contrasts) using SPM2, with cluster thresholds and coordinates presented in figures/tables. Healthy participant results are reported and generalizable to adults within the review age range. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in 18 healthy adult participants (mean age 42±12, within 17–65) that uses a social motor response task manipulating social inclusion/exclusion. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (SPM2) with results thresholded and controlled using whole-brain FDR and coordinates/tables provided for significant activations (e.g., frontal operculum, dorsal ACC, ventral striatum, amygdala). Results are reported for the healthy group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=26, ages ~24) using a social-emotional (empathy/emotional perspective-taking) paradigm (SELF/OTHER tasks). Group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts are reported (SELF vs baseline and OTHER vs baseline) with results presented in tables and figures; common effects across the whole sample were thresholded at p<0.05 FWE-corrected (whole-brain), and coordinates of activations are listed. Healthy adult group results are separable from any subgroup analyses (gender effects are reported separately). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activations). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self/friend/unfamiliar face and name recognition — perception/understanding of self and others). The sample comprises healthy adults (age 18–24; N=35 with usable data). Group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses were performed using SPM5 and reported (tables of peak coordinates, cluster-level inferences, contrasts such as Sf–Ff, Fn–Sn, S+F–2C). The paper reports univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and coordinates for healthy participants; it is not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult samples (Experiment 1: n=20 females, mean age 20.8; Experiment 2: n=30, mean age 21.2). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate contrasts (PD > Gamble and in-group > out-group), with tables of coordinates (Tables 2–5), statistical thresholds, and figures. Whole-brain voxelwise results are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults (ages within 17–65). Although the paper includes ROI and connectivity/Granger analyses, it also provides the required whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy control groups. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI or only resting-state) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (neural responses to social hierarchy) in healthy adults. The sample includes healthy right-handed adults within the 19–43 age range (n=24 per social experiment; total 48 analyzed in social paradigms), meeting the 17–65 requirement. The paper reports group-level, univariate, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., ‘superior player > inferior player’), FDR-corrected maps, and detailed coordinate tables and figures (Tables 1–3, Figures 2–5), clearly identified as healthy/control group results. Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI experiment that directly probes social communication (viewing, imitating, and producing facial expressions and social hand gestures). The abstract reports group-level task-evoked neural activations in canonical regions (inferior parietal lobule, frontal operculum) and notes differences in activation locations, indicating voxelwise/whole-brain univariate results rather than ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. The study appears to report results from human participants (healthy group) and is published in J Cogn Neurosci (2008). No indication in the provided text of patient-only or non-adult samples, nor of analyses limited to ROI/connectivity. One minor uncertainty is that the excerpt does not state the exact participant ages/number in the provided snippet; however, the paper clearly presents group-level, generalizable task activation maps for a healthy participant sample, meeting the review inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction (friendship/affiliation) in healthy adults (N=28, right-handed, mean age 22.6, range 19–27), satisfying the sample criterion (17–65). The task probes social-related constructs (affiliation/attachment, empathy, reward) using an active social interaction simulation. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (random-effects ANOVA and t-contrasts) with familywise error correction and provides tables of significant clusters/coordinates (Table 1) and figures. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of communicative speech (social communication) in healthy adult participants (n=29, ages 18–24). The tasks directly probe social-related processing (communication vs description; familiar vs unfamiliar actors). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise random-effects analyses with contrasts (communication vs description; task vs control), cluster-corrected statistics and peak coordinates in tables/figures, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and is eligible for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-concept processing in healthy adults (n=26; mean age 29.4). The experiment required judgments about social versus animal-function word pairs (a social-related task). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs. animal; social vs. fixation) with tables and figures giving MNI coordinates and statistical thresholds, plus conjunction and ROI analyses. Results for the healthy control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not connectivity-only or ROI-only. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (16 healthy male participants, mean age 28.6) using an interactive social paradigm (competitive reaction-time task provoking reactive aggression). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise analyses conducted in SPM2 with thresholding and tabulated coordinates (Tables 1–3) and activation maps for task contrasts (retaliation, observing opponent, etc.). Findings are reported for the healthy cohort and are generalizable to healthy adults within the eligible age range. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and includes whole-brain task activation maps and coordinate tables. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=11, ages 18–32). The task involves face perception and spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge—falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate contrasts (e.g., faces associated with behaviors vs novel faces; disgusting vs aggressive), with Talairach coordinates, t-values, cluster sizes, and random-effects group analyses, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, or non-empirical limitations apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=16 recruited; data from 15 used; ages 20–28), using a task probing perception/attribution of self-generated versus external movement (detection of visuo-motor and visuo-proprioceptive synchrony), which maps onto the review construct ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (Aa–As, Pa–Ps) with cluster results and stereotactic coordinates in tables and figures. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes within-group healthy adult results generalizable to the target population. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social interaction using virtual characters that directly investigates social-related processing (gaze, social communication, self-involvement). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=18 recruited; analyses on n=17), ages within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., SOC>ARB, ARB>SOC, ME>OTHER, OTHER>ME) with SPM results, stereotactic coordinates, statistical thresholds, figures and tables of activations, allowing inference to the healthy adult population. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (13 right-handed males, age 19–36) that explicitly probes social cognition (Theory of Mind and empathy) using a task designed to elicit social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM2) with statistical maps and tables of coordinates for contrasts such as ‘ToM – Physical 1’ and ‘Empathy – Physical 2’, and a conjunction/interaction analysis. Results are presented as univariate, whole-brain task-evoked activations generalizable to the healthy control group. No ROI-only, connectivity-only, or exclusively between-group contrasts restriction applies. Participant ages fall within 17–65. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (anger prosody/social communication) in a healthy adult sample (N=15, mean age 24.4, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses using SPM2 random-effects (explicit contrasts such as anger vs. neutral, attention effects) with coordinates and cluster results shown in Table 1 and figures. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, nor to between-group contrasts, and healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps are clearly described. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (a social-related task: perception/understanding of self) in healthy adults (12 right-handed male undergraduates, mean age 19.36, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., self vs. familiar, familiar vs. unknown, distracter vs. null) analyzed with SPM and provides tables of stereotactic coordinates and statistical maps. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy control group are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI of a social-related task (impression formation about other people vs objects), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=14; ages 18.3–23.7), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., person-impression > others; impression formation > sequencing) with thresholding and tables of MNI coordinates and cluster sizes (P < 0.001, random-effects), satisfying whole-brain univariate reporting. This is an empirical fMRI study (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only), so it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study reporting two separate fMRI experiments that investigate understanding intentions in social interaction (a social-cognitive task). The abstract explicitly describes task-evoked activations (anterior paracingulate cortex), indicating whole-brain group-level activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. The population is described in standard cognitive-neuroscience terms and is consistent with healthy adult samples (no indication that only clinical or out-of-range ages were studied). The paper therefore meets: (1) use of task-based fMRI for social processing, (2) inclusion of healthy adult participants, and (3) reporting of group-level whole-brain activation findings generalizable to healthy adults. If full participant ages turn out to be outside 17–65, inclusion should be reconsidered, but available information supports inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment) in healthy adults. Sample: 19 healthy right-handed adults (mean ages within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses and multiple univariate contrasts (G–N, E–N, E–G, G–E) with coordinate tables and figures (thresholds and extent reported). Results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI evidence in healthy adult participants.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, ages 21–28). The task is social (cooperation and competition) clearly relevant to social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM second-level random-effects contrasts) with tables of significant activations and coordinates for contrasts such as cooperation vs. independent, competition vs. independent, and direct comparisons; thresholding and cluster extents are described. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65 range, and healthy-group results are reported). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study (NeuroImage 2004) that used a social-related task: healthy adult participants (N=13, right-handed, mean age 27.2) passively watched realistic video clips depicting social interactions (affiliation/authority relations). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (relational vs. alone; relational vs. rest) with family-wise correction (P ≤ 0.05) and provides tables of Talairach coordinates and figures of activation maps. Results for the healthy adult sample are reported directly and are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, between-group, or non-adult samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using a social-interaction paradigm (iterated sequential Prisoner’s Dilemma) and tests implicit social judgments of faces (affiliation/moral status). Participants are healthy adults (imaging sample: 11 right-handed subjects, age 21–36). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., cooperator vs neutral, defector vs neutral; tables of coordinates and SPM random-effects analyses are provided). Analyses are not limited to ROI- or connectivity-only approaches. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study is an event-related fMRI investigation of social evaluation (trustworthiness judgments of faces), involving healthy adult participants (16 recruited, 14 included in group analyses; ages 18–30). It reports group-level, random-effects, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (SPM) including main effects and contrasts, with coordinates and figures (amygdala, STS, fusiform, insula) and small-volume-corrected as well as whole-brain thresholded results. The task and analyses clearly target social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). It is empirical, not ROI-only, and provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (n=10) examining social-cognitive processes (empathy and forgiveness). The paper reports group-level task-evoked brain activations (e.g., left superior frontal gyrus, orbitofrontal gyrus, precuneus, anterior middle temporal and inferior frontal gyri, posterior cingulate), indicating whole-brain univariate results rather than ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are healthy adults and the reported effects are within-group task activations generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are apparent from the full text provided.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social/emotional processing (implicit emotion task: gender identification of angry and happy faces vs neutral shapes) in healthy adults (N=30, mean age 24.2). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., FAC-angry > neutral, FAC-happy > neutral) using random-effects analyses and provides whole-brain results in text/tables/figures. It therefore meets inclusion criteria: social-related task, healthy adult sample within 17–65, and reported whole-brain task-evoked activation maps/contrasts. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25, mean age 25.2, within 17–65) that investigates face processing (facial color), a social-perception construct relevant to 'Perception and Understanding of Others'. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (natural-colored face vs natural-scrambled image) with cluster coordinates and statistics used to define ROIs, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task effects generalizable to adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of active interpersonal touch (a social-related task) in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxel-wise univariate contrasts for task conditions (anticipation and performance phases) with statistical maps and cluster coordinates (tables and figures), and uses a tactile localizer mask. Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group and generalizable within that sample. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes whole-brain task activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study uses a social task (multiround Ultimatum Game) probing social decision-making. It includes a healthy adult group (n=15; ages 19–28) and reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (unfair > fair offers) analyzed with SPM8 and one-sample t-tests/ANOVA, with results presented in tables/figures (coordinates, cluster statistics) and threshold information. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable within the adult range (19–28). The paper therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social processing; healthy adult sample reported; whole-brain univariate maps). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of tactile priming effects on social judgment in healthy adults (N=20, age range 23–39). The task involves social-related processing (judgments of social coordination vs relationship familiarity). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., rough > smooth, rough > no priming) and tables of peak coordinates and FDR-corrected results, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Participants are healthy adults within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy/control group. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and includes whole-brain task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This empirical fMRI study examines face perception (a social-perception/understanding-of-others task) and includes a healthy adult sample (ages 18–37). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses (faces > diverse objects) with tables of coordinates and figures (e.g., Table 3, whole-brain regression results and maps) that are generalizable to healthy adults. Adult participant results and ROI data (e.g., FFA coordinates and volumes for the adult subgroup) are reported separately. The study is empirical, uses task-based fMRI, and provides univariate whole-brain activation data suitable for inclusion in a meta-analysis of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The study uses task-based fMRI with a social-perception paradigm (point-light biological motion vs scrambled motion). It reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects GLM contrasts in healthy adults (n=48; ages 20–35) with voxelwise results and cluster-corrected thresholds, tables of peak coordinates and figures (e.g., biological > scrambled in adults, Sex×Condition ANOVA). The adult healthy group results are reported separately from child/adolescent analyses. Analyses are not ROI-only and include univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (affiliation vs isolation) in healthy adults. It includes a healthy younger adult group (n=16; mean age 20.75, within the 17–65 range) and reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., social vs nonsocial; affiliation vs isolation) with tables of peak coordinates and statistical maps, as well as conjunction and within-group analyses referenced in the methods/tables. Although an older adult group (>65) is also included, results for the healthy younger adult group are reported separately and whole-brain task-evoked effects for the healthy group are available in the text/tables. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state, and provides univariate task activation maps generalizable to healthy adults, so it satisfies the inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults (N=20, mean age 22) that investigates social-communicative processing (communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (vocal > nonvocal; communicative > noncommunicative) with statistical thresholding (FDR q < .05) and peak coordinates, and presents whole-brain results in figures and tables. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy adult group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of eye gaze and identity — social communication/perception of others) in healthy adult participants (n=9, mean age 24). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked activations (face > scrambled contrasts; cluster thresholds, stereotaxic coordinates in Table 1 and figures), and contrasts between task conditions (attention to identity vs gaze; averted vs direct gaze). Results are not limited to ROI analyses or connectivity-only methods. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (causal attributions/self-responsibility) in healthy adults (12 neurologically healthy males, ages 20–51). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (internal vs external attributions; self-serving vs non-self-serving) with peak coordinates and statistical thresholds (SPM fixed-effects results reported at voxelwise P<0.05 corrected, with follow-up random-effects ROI checks). Results for the healthy control group are reported explicitly and in a form (tables of coordinates and figures) acceptable for inclusion. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes appropriate age range, and is empirical). Although sample size is modest and fixed-effects are emphasized, whole-brain univariate activations for the healthy group are provided and generalizable analyses are presented, so the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=10, mean age 26.9) that uses a social-cognition relevant task (self-face vs familiar-other perception). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate contrasts (self>other; other>self) with MNI coordinates, statistical thresholds, cluster correction, and task-versus-rest contrasts. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and results are clearly reported for the healthy adult group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of facial emotion processing (social communication/perception of others) in healthy adults (N=29, ages 20–35). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and tables of coordinates (Table 1) with FWE-corrected results and figures showing bilateral amygdala and other whole-brain activations. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain univariate results for the healthy control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes appropriate age range and healthy sample). Thus it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20, ages 20–34) that investigates neural responses to observed hand and foot actions (mirror system) using task-based paradigms (Action Observation and Execution). Analyses report group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate results (conjunctions and contrasts) with thresholding and peak coordinates provided in Table 1 and figures (P < 0.05 corrected), which fulfill the whole-brain evidence requirement. The task concerns perception/understanding of others’ actions (fits the social-related construct: Perception and Understanding of Others). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI of self-related processing (general and contextual self-judgments), which falls under social-related constructs (Perception/Understanding of Self). Sample comprises 24 healthy adult participants (ages ~21–24), meeting the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise random-effects analyses and provides multiple tables of coordinates and figures (Tables II–V, whole-brain regression and interaction contrasts), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is empirical task fMRI (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only), and healthy-group effects are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (social expectancy violations along warmth and competence). Sample comprises healthy adult undergraduates (mean age 20.4; n=12 included in analyses), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM analyses and provides voxelwise results with Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, and statistical thresholds (reported contrasts and ROIs derived from whole-brain contrasts). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and results for healthy adults are reported). Although the sample size is small, the study nonetheless reports whole-brain task-evoked group results generalizable to healthy adults and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition and gaze integration; links to theory-of-mind), meeting the review topic. It includes a healthy younger adult group (N=20; age range 17–27) that falls within the required 17–65 range. The paper reports whole‑brain, group-level task-evoked analyses: although they used partial least squares (a multivariate whole-brain decomposition), results are presented as whole-brain patterns with peak coordinates, bootstrap ratios, and cluster tables and figures (i.e., group-level, voxelwise whole-brain evidence clearly described). The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed‑connectivity only, and provides healthy-group maps and coordinates suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

While this is an fMRI study of social rejection (Cyberball) with a healthy adult group (ages 23.9–38.8) and reports whole-brain task contrasts, the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map clearly attributable to the healthy adult group alone. Main whole-brain results are reported for the combined sample (adolescents + adults). Adult-specific findings are reported primarily via an interaction and small-volume-corrected (SVC) ROI/post-hoc tests (right vlPFC), and the within-adult contrasts cited are reported only as post-hoc/SVC/unadjusted tests rather than an unmasked whole-brain adult-group map or table of whole-brain adult coordinates. Thus it fails the requirement to report a standalone, whole-brain, group-level univariate task map for the healthy adult group, so it must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults. Tasks: a self-reference effect task (Self, Mother, Letter) and a social attribution task (Friends vs. Bumper Cars) directly probe perception/understanding of self and others. Sample: healthy adult participants (n=17 analyzed for RPT; subset n=11 for SAT), mean age ~21.5, within 17–65. Analyses: group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., Self vs. Letter, Mother vs. Letter, Friends vs. Bumper Cars) with tables of Talairach coordinates and FDR thresholds. Not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, nor to special/clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of processing dynamic facial expressions (social perception/communication) in a sample of healthy adults (n=51; mean age 22.5, right-handed). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (dynamic expression > dynamic mosaic) analyzed with random-effects models and FWE-corrected whole-brain thresholds; results are presented as tables of coordinates and statistical parametric maps. The healthy-group whole-brain univariate task effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes appropriate age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (78 participants, ages 18–40) including multiple social-related tasks (false belief/ToM, intentional triangles, eyes intention, trustworthiness, vocalizations, face tasks) that probe perception/understanding of others. Group-level whole-brain univariate random-effects analyses are reported (voxelwise results thresholded at p<0.05 FWE) with peak tables and supplementary maps. The healthy group results are clearly reported and generalizable to adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, and participants are within the 17–65 range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Although the study uses fMRI with a social task (cyberball) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=17, ages within 17–65), the full text does not report a within-group, whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., inclusion>passive watching main effect in HC).
